Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Variable-Property Material Synthesizing Instrument

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) grant supports acquisition of a state-of-the-art variable-property material synthesizing instrument (OBJET Connex500) for leading-edge research on functionally-graded material systems at Texas A&M University-Kingsville (TAMUK). The instrument directly combines two component materials in specific concentrations and structures to design novel variable-property material systems. With direct fabrication, complex systems can be fabricated in a single build process, eliminating design restrictions and saving energy. The instrumentation will advance fundamental research on the design of novel variable-property material systems, enabling the development of compliant mechanisms and smart structures, and formats for organic semiconductors, superconductors, and other organic electronic devices.

The instrumentation will support research by a multidisciplinary team and by TAMUK undergraduate students. Underrepresented graduate and undergraduate Hispanic students will be given access to enhanced curriculum and the state-of-the-art instrumentation; this experience will give them unique skills and broader career options. The instrumentation will be featured in summer outreach programs and will be made available to regional educational institutions. The instrumentation will spur enhanced research competitiveness and innovation in South Texas-an economically challenged area. Local industry will gain access through the Javelina Innovation Center, which was established to aid local industry in simulating, designing, and manufacturing novel products in a low-cost manner.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) grant supports the acquisition of an instrument (OBJET Connex500) at Texas A&M University-Kingsville (TAMUK). The instrument can directly combine two component materials to make material property variable and meet specific material property requirements. Complex material systems can be fabricated by this instrument in a single build process. This instrument has been available and used for research, teaching and outreach activities at TAMUK since 2014. Students and faculty members use this instrument to directly fabricate components, structures, mechanisms and devices. Some novel systems have been designed by the graduate students and faculty members of the project team and published in international journal or conference papers. Over 20 graduate students who major in engineering or science and are advised by the faculty members of this project team have graduated through research activities of this project.

The instrument is used by faculty members and graduate students for their research projects, which is helping them to develop novel mechanical, structural and electronic systems and devices. It is used for undergraduate senior design projects, course projects and outreach activities. The instrument is providing research opportunities for engineering and science students and attracts them to advanced engineering and science investigations. The instrument is providing students (especially the underrepresented Hispanic students in South Texas) with the access to state-of-the-art instrumentation. It attracts K-12 students (especially underrepresented young Hispanics in South Texas) to pursue STEM education.
